1""" 

2GUI neutral widgets 

3=================== 

4 

5Widgets that are designed to work for any of the GUI backends. 

6All of these widgets require you to predefine a `matplotlib.axes.Axes` 

7instance and pass that as the first parameter. Matplotlib doesn't try to 

8be too smart with respect to layout -- you will have to figure out how 

9wide and tall you want your Axes to be to accommodate your widget. 

10""" 

11

28class LockDraw: 

29 """ 

30 Some widgets, like the cursor, draw onto the canvas, and this is not 

31 desirable under all circumstances, like when the toolbar is in zoom-to-rect 

32 mode and drawing a rectangle. To avoid this, a widget can acquire a 

33 canvas' lock with ``canvas.widgetlock(widget)`` before drawing on the 

34 canvas; this will prevent other widgets from doing so at the same time (if 

35 they also try to acquire the lock first). 

36 """ 

37 

38 def __init__(self): 

39 self._owner = None 

40 

41 def __call__(self, o): 

42 """Reserve the lock for *o*.""" 

43 if not self.available(o): 43 ↛ 44line 43 didn't jump to line 44, because the condition on line 43 was never true

44 raise ValueError('already locked') 

45 self._owner = o 

46 

47 def release(self, o): 

48 """Release the lock from *o*.""" 

49 if not self.available(o): 49 ↛ 50line 49 didn't jump to line 50, because the condition on line 49 was never true

50 raise ValueError('you do not own this lock') 

51 self._owner = None 

52 

53 def available(self, o): 

54 """Return whether drawing is available to *o*.""" 

55 return not self.locked() or self.isowner(o) 

56 

57 def isowner(self, o): 

58 """Return whether *o* owns this lock.""" 

59 return self._owner is o 

60 

61 def locked(self): 

62 """Return whether the lock is currently held by an owner.""" 

63 return self._owner is not None

66class Widget: 

67 """ 

68 Abstract base class for GUI neutral widgets. 

69 """ 

70 drawon = True 

71 eventson = True 

72 _active = True 

73 

74 def set_active(self, active): 

75 """Set whether the widget is active.""" 

76 self._active = active 

77 

78 def get_active(self): 

79 """Get whether the widget is active.""" 

80 return self._active 

81 

82 # set_active is overridden by SelectorWidgets. 

83 active = property(get_active, set_active, doc="Is the widget active?") 

84 

85 def ignore(self, event): 

86 """ 

87 Return whether *event* should be ignored. 

88 

89 This method should be called at the beginning of any event callback. 

90 """ 

91 return not self.active 

92 

93 def _changed_canvas(self): 

94 """ 

95 Someone has switched the canvas on us! 

96 

97 This happens if `savefig` needs to save to a format the previous 

98 backend did not support (e.g. saving a figure using an Agg based 

99 backend saved to a vector format). 

100 

101 Returns 

102 ------- 

103 bool 

104 True if the canvas has been changed. 

105 

106 """ 

107 return self.canvas is not self.ax.figure.canvas

110class AxesWidget(Widget): 

111 """ 

112 Widget connected to a single `~matplotlib.axes.Axes`. 

113 

114 To guarantee that the widget remains responsive and not garbage-collected, 

115 a reference to the object should be maintained by the user. 

116 

117 This is necessary because the callback registry 

118 maintains only weak-refs to the functions, which are member 

119 functions of the widget. If there are no references to the widget 

120 object it may be garbage collected which will disconnect the callbacks. 

121 

122 Attributes 

123 ---------- 

124 ax : `~matplotlib.axes.Axes` 

125 The parent Axes for the widget. 

126 canvas : `~matplotlib.backend_bases.FigureCanvasBase` 

127 The parent figure canvas for the widget. 

128 active : bool 

129 If False, the widget does not respond to events. 

130 """ 

131 

132 def __init__(self, ax): 

133 self.ax = ax 

134 self.canvas = ax.figure.canvas 

135 self._cids = [] 

136 

137 def connect_event(self, event, callback): 

138 """ 

139 Connect a callback function with an event. 

140 

141 This should be used in lieu of ``figure.canvas.mpl_connect`` since this 

142 function stores callback ids for later clean up. 

143 """ 

144 cid = self.canvas.mpl_connect(event, callback) 

145 self._cids.append(cid) 

146 

147 def disconnect_events(self): 

148 """Disconnect all events created by this widget.""" 

149 for c in self._cids: 

150 self.canvas.mpl_disconnect(c)

153class Button(AxesWidget): 

154 """ 

155 A GUI neutral button. 

156 

157 For the button to remain responsive you must keep a reference to it. 

158 Call `.on_clicked` to connect to the button. 

159 

160 Attributes 

161 ---------- 

162 ax 

163 The `matplotlib.axes.Axes` the button renders into. 

164 label 

165 A `matplotlib.text.Text` instance. 

166 color 

167 The color of the button when not hovering. 

168 hovercolor 

169 The color of the button when hovering. 

170 """ 

171 

172 def __init__(self, ax, label, image=None, 

173 color='0.85', hovercolor='0.95', *, useblit=True): 

174 """ 

175 Parameters 

176 ---------- 

177 ax : `~matplotlib.axes.Axes` 

178 The `~.axes.Axes` instance the button will be placed into. 

179 label : str 

180 The button text. 

181 image : array-like or PIL Image 

182 The image to place in the button, if not *None*. The parameter is 

183 directly forwarded to `~matplotlib.axes.Axes.imshow`. 

184 color : color 

185 The color of the button when not activated. 

186 hovercolor : color 

187 The color of the button when the mouse is over it. 

188 useblit : bool, default: True 

189 Use blitting for faster drawing if supported by the backend. 

190 See the tutorial :doc:`/tutorials/advanced/blitting` for details. 

191 """ 

192 super().__init__(ax) 

193 

194 if image is not None: 

195 ax.imshow(image) 

196 self.label = ax.text(0.5, 0.5, label, 

197 verticalalignment='center', 

198 horizontalalignment='center', 

199 transform=ax.transAxes) 

200 

201 self._useblit = useblit and self.canvas.supports_blit 

202 

203 self._observers = cbook.CallbackRegistry(signals=["clicked"]) 

204 

205 self.connect_event('button_press_event', self._click) 

206 self.connect_event('button_release_event', self._release) 

207 self.connect_event('motion_notify_event', self._motion) 

208 ax.set_navigate(False) 

209 ax.set_facecolor(color) 

210 ax.set_xticks([]) 

211 ax.set_yticks([]) 

212 self.color = color 

213 self.hovercolor = hovercolor 

214 

215 def _click(self, event): 

216 if self.ignore(event) or event.inaxes != self.ax or not self.eventson: 

217 return 

218 if event.canvas.mouse_grabber != self.ax: 

219 event.canvas.grab_mouse(self.ax) 

220 

221 def _release(self, event): 

222 if self.ignore(event) or event.canvas.mouse_grabber != self.ax: 

223 return 

224 event.canvas.release_mouse(self.ax) 

225 if self.eventson and event.inaxes == self.ax: 

226 self._observers.process('clicked', event) 

227 

228 def _motion(self, event): 

229 if self.ignore(event): 

230 return 

231 c = self.hovercolor if event.inaxes == self.ax else self.color 

232 if not colors.same_color(c, self.ax.get_facecolor()): 

233 self.ax.set_facecolor(c) 

234 if self.drawon: 

235 if self._useblit: 

236 self.ax.draw_artist(self.ax) 

237 self.canvas.blit(self.ax.bbox) 

238 else: 

239 self.canvas.draw() 

240 

241 def on_clicked(self, func): 

242 """ 

243 Connect the callback function *func* to button click events. 

244 

245 Returns a connection id, which can be used to disconnect the callback. 

246 """ 

247 return self._observers.connect('clicked', lambda event: func(event)) 

248 

249 def disconnect(self, cid): 

250 """Remove the callback function with connection id *cid*.""" 

251 self._observers.disconnect(cid)

301 def _stepped_value(self, val): 

302 """Return *val* coerced to closest number in the ``valstep`` grid.""" 

303 if isinstance(self.valstep, Number): 

304 val = (self.valmin 

305 + round((val - self.valmin) / self.valstep) * self.valstep) 

306 elif self.valstep is not None: 

307 valstep = np.asanyarray(self.valstep) 

308 if valstep.ndim != 1: 308 ↛ 309line 308 didn't jump to line 309, because the condition on line 308 was never true

309 raise ValueError( 

310 f"valstep must have 1 dimension but has {valstep.ndim}" 

311 ) 

312 val = valstep[np.argmin(np.abs(valstep - val))] 

313 return val

332class Slider(SliderBase): 

333 """ 

334 A slider representing a floating point range. 

335 

336 Create a slider from *valmin* to *valmax* in Axes *ax*. For the slider to 

337 remain responsive you must maintain a reference to it. Call 

338 :meth:`on_changed` to connect to the slider event. 

339 

340 Attributes 

341 ---------- 

342 val : float 

343 Slider value. 

344 """ 

345 

346 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.7", name="valinit") 

347 def __init__(self, ax, label, valmin, valmax, valinit=0.5, valfmt=None, 

348 closedmin=True, closedmax=True, slidermin=None, 

349 slidermax=None, dragging=True, valstep=None, 

350 orientation='horizontal', *, initcolor='r', 

351 track_color='lightgrey', handle_style=None, **kwargs): 

352 """ 

353 Parameters 

354 ---------- 

355 ax : Axes 

356 The Axes to put the slider in. 

357 

358 label : str 

359 Slider label. 

360 

361 valmin : float 

362 The minimum value of the slider. 

363 

364 valmax : float 

365 The maximum value of the slider. 

366 

367 valinit : float, default: 0.5 

368 The slider initial position. 

369 

370 valfmt : str, default: None 

371 %-format string used to format the slider value. If None, a 

372 `.ScalarFormatter` is used instead. 

373 

374 closedmin : bool, default: True 

375 Whether the slider interval is closed on the bottom. 

376 

377 closedmax : bool, default: True 

378 Whether the slider interval is closed on the top. 

379 

380 slidermin : Slider, default: None 

381 Do not allow the current slider to have a value less than 

382 the value of the Slider *slidermin*. 

383 

384 slidermax : Slider, default: None 

385 Do not allow the current slider to have a value greater than 

386 the value of the Slider *slidermax*. 

387 

388 dragging : bool, default: True 

389 If True the slider can be dragged by the mouse. 

390 

391 valstep : float or array-like, default: None 

392 If a float, the slider will snap to multiples of *valstep*. 

393 If an array the slider will snap to the values in the array. 

394 

395 orientation : {'horizontal', 'vertical'}, default: 'horizontal' 

396 The orientation of the slider. 

397 

398 initcolor : color, default: 'r' 

399 The color of the line at the *valinit* position. Set to ``'none'`` 

400 for no line. 

401 

402 track_color : color, default: 'lightgrey' 

403 The color of the background track. The track is accessible for 

404 further styling via the *track* attribute. 

405 

406 handle_style : dict 

407 Properties of the slider handle. Default values are 

408 

409 ========= ===== ======= ======================================== 

410 Key Value Default Description 

411 ========= ===== ======= ======================================== 

412 facecolor color 'white' The facecolor of the slider handle. 

413 edgecolor color '.75' The edgecolor of the slider handle. 

414 size int 10 The size of the slider handle in points. 

415 ========= ===== ======= ======================================== 

416 

417 Other values will be transformed as marker{foo} and passed to the 

418 `~.Line2D` constructor. e.g. ``handle_style = {'style'='x'}`` will 

419 result in ``markerstyle = 'x'``. 

420 

421 Notes 

422 ----- 

423 Additional kwargs are passed on to ``self.poly`` which is the 

424 `~matplotlib.patches.Polygon` that draws the slider knob. See the 

425 `.Polygon` documentation for valid property names (``facecolor``, 

426 ``edgecolor``, ``alpha``, etc.). 

427 """

527 def _update(self, event): 

528 """Update the slider position.""" 

529 if self.ignore(event) or event.button != 1: 

530 return 

531 

532 if event.name == 'button_press_event' and event.inaxes == self.ax: 

533 self.drag_active = True 

534 event.canvas.grab_mouse(self.ax) 

535 

536 if not self.drag_active: 

537 return 

538 

539 elif ((event.name == 'button_release_event') or 

540 (event.name == 'button_press_event' and 

541 event.inaxes != self.ax)): 

542 self.drag_active = False 

543 event.canvas.release_mouse(self.ax) 

544 return 

545 if self.orientation == 'vertical': 

546 val = self._value_in_bounds(event.ydata) 

547 else: 

548 val = self._value_in_bounds(event.xdata) 

549 if val not in [None, self.val]:

552 def _format(self, val): 

553 """Pretty-print *val*."""

555 return self.valfmt % val

557 _, s, _ = self._fmt.format_ticks([self.valmin, val, self.valmax]) 

558 # fmt.get_offset is actually the multiplicative factor, if any. 

559 return s + self._fmt.get_offset()

604class RangeSlider(SliderBase): 

605 """ 

606 A slider representing a range of floating point values. Defines the min and 

607 max of the range via the *val* attribute as a tuple of (min, max). 

608 

609 Create a slider that defines a range contained within [*valmin*, *valmax*] 

610 in Axes *ax*. For the slider to remain responsive you must maintain a 

611 reference to it. Call :meth:`on_changed` to connect to the slider event. 

612 

613 Attributes 

614 ---------- 

615 val : tuple of float 

616 Slider value. 

617 """ 

618 

619 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.7", name="valinit") 

620 def __init__( 

621 self, 

622 ax, 

623 label, 

624 valmin, 

625 valmax, 

626 valinit=None, 

627 valfmt=None, 

628 closedmin=True, 

629 closedmax=True, 

630 dragging=True, 

631 valstep=None, 

632 orientation="horizontal", 

633 track_color='lightgrey', 

634 handle_style=None, 

635 **kwargs, 

636 ): 

637 """ 

638 Parameters 

639 ---------- 

640 ax : Axes 

641 The Axes to put the slider in. 

642 

643 label : str 

644 Slider label. 

645 

646 valmin : float 

647 The minimum value of the slider. 

648 

649 valmax : float 

650 The maximum value of the slider. 

651 

652 valinit : tuple of float or None, default: None 

653 The initial positions of the slider. If None the initial positions 

654 will be at the 25th and 75th percentiles of the range. 

655 

656 valfmt : str, default: None 

657 %-format string used to format the slider values. If None, a 

658 `.ScalarFormatter` is used instead. 

659 

660 closedmin : bool, default: True 

661 Whether the slider interval is closed on the bottom. 

662 

663 closedmax : bool, default: True 

664 Whether the slider interval is closed on the top. 

665 

666 dragging : bool, default: True 

667 If True the slider can be dragged by the mouse. 

668 

669 valstep : float, default: None 

670 If given, the slider will snap to multiples of *valstep*. 

671 

672 orientation : {'horizontal', 'vertical'}, default: 'horizontal' 

673 The orientation of the slider. 

674 

675 track_color : color, default: 'lightgrey' 

676 The color of the background track. The track is accessible for

803 def _update_selection_poly(self, vmin, vmax): 

804 """ 

805 Update the vertices of the *self.poly* slider in-place 

806 to cover the data range *vmin*, *vmax*. 

807 """ 

808 # The vertices are positioned 

809 # 1 ------ 2 

810 # | | 

811 # 0, 4 ---- 3 

812 verts = self.poly.xy 

813 if self.orientation == "vertical": 

814 verts[0] = verts[4] = .25, vmin 

815 verts[1] = .25, vmax 

816 verts[2] = .75, vmax 

817 verts[3] = .75, vmin 

818 else: 

819 verts[0] = verts[4] = vmin, .25 

820 verts[1] = vmin, .75 

821 verts[2] = vmax, .75 

822 verts[3] = vmax, .25

824 def _min_in_bounds(self, min): 

825 """Ensure the new min value is between valmin and self.val[1].""" 

826 if min <= self.valmin: 

827 if not self.closedmin: 827 ↛ 828line 827 didn't jump to line 828, because the condition on line 827 was never true

828 return self.val[0] 

829 min = self.valmin 

830 

831 if min > self.val[1]: 831 ↛ 832line 831 didn't jump to line 832, because the condition on line 831 was never true

832 min = self.val[1] 

833 return self._stepped_value(min) 

834 

835 def _max_in_bounds(self, max): 

836 """Ensure the new max value is between valmax and self.val[0].""" 

837 if max >= self.valmax: 

838 if not self.closedmax: 838 ↛ 839line 838 didn't jump to line 839, because the condition on line 838 was never true

839 return self.val[1] 

840 max = self.valmax 

841 

842 if max <= self.val[0]: 

843 max = self.val[0] 

844 return self._stepped_value(max)

846 def _value_in_bounds(self, vals): 

847 """Clip min, max values to the bounds.""" 

848 return (self._min_in_bounds(vals[0]), self._max_in_bounds(vals[1]))

850 def _update_val_from_pos(self, pos): 

851 """Update the slider value based on a given position.""" 

852 idx = np.argmin(np.abs(self.val - pos)) 

853 if idx == 0: 

854 val = self._min_in_bounds(pos) 

855 self.set_min(val) 

856 else: 

857 val = self._max_in_bounds(pos) 

858 self.set_max(val) 

859 if self._active_handle: 

860 if self.orientation == "vertical": 

861 self._active_handle.set_ydata([val]) 

862 else: 

863 self._active_handle.set_xdata([val]) 

864 

865 def _update(self, event): 

866 """Update the slider position.""" 

867 if self.ignore(event) or event.button != 1: 

868 return 

869 

870 if event.name == "button_press_event" and event.inaxes == self.ax: 

871 self.drag_active = True 

872 event.canvas.grab_mouse(self.ax) 

873 

874 if not self.drag_active: 

875 return 

876 

877 elif (event.name == "button_release_event") or ( 

878 event.name == "button_press_event" and event.inaxes != self.ax 

879 ): 

880 self.drag_active = False 

881 event.canvas.release_mouse(self.ax) 

882 self._active_handle = None 

883 return 

884 

885 # determine which handle was grabbed 

886 if self.orientation == "vertical": 

887 handle_index = np.argmin( 

888 np.abs([h.get_ydata()[0] - event.ydata for h in self._handles]) 

889 ) 

890 else: 

891 handle_index = np.argmin( 

892 np.abs([h.get_xdata()[0] - event.xdata for h in self._handles]) 

893 ) 

894 handle = self._handles[handle_index] 

895 

896 # these checks ensure smooth behavior if the handles swap which one 

897 # has a higher value. i.e. if one is dragged over and past the other. 

898 if handle is not self._active_handle: 

899 self._active_handle = handle 

900 

901 if self.orientation == "vertical": 

902 self._update_val_from_pos(event.ydata) 

903 else: 

904 self._update_val_from_pos(event.xdata)

910 else:

913 )

915 s1 += self._fmt.get_offset() 

916 s2 += self._fmt.get_offset() 

917 # Use f string to avoid issues with backslashes when cast to a str 

918 return f"({s1}, {s2})"

1423 # this is a hack to figure out where the cursor should go. 

1424 # we draw the text up to where the cursor should go, measure 

1425 # and save its dimensions, draw the real text, then put the cursor 

1426 # at the saved dimensions

1429 # yet, which should be fine as we're going to repeatedly re-render the 

1430 # figure later anyways.

1434 text = self.text_disp.get_text() # Save value before overwriting it. 

1435 widthtext = text[:self.cursor_index] 

1436 

1437 bb_text = self.text_disp.get_window_extent()

1439 bb_widthtext = self.text_disp.get_window_extent() 

1440 

1441 if bb_text.y0 == bb_text.y1: # Restoring the height if no text. 

1442 bb_text.y0 -= bb_widthtext.height / 2 

1443 bb_text.y1 += bb_widthtext.height / 2 

1444 elif not widthtext: # Keep width to 0. 

1445 bb_text.x1 = bb_text.x0 

1446 else: # Move the cursor using width of bb_widthtext. 

1447 bb_text.x1 = bb_text.x0 + bb_widthtext.width

1893 valinit=getattr(targetfig.subplotpars, name))

1900 self.sliderwspace, self.sliderhspace]: 

1901 slider.closedmax = False 

1902 for slider in [self.sliderright, self.slidertop]: 

1903 slider.closedmin = False 

1904 

1905 # constraints 

1906 self.sliderleft.slidermax = self.sliderright 

1907 self.sliderright.slidermin = self.sliderleft 

1908 self.sliderbottom.slidermax = self.slidertop 

1909 self.slidertop.slidermin = self.sliderbottom 

1910 

1911 bax = toolfig.add_axes([0.8, 0.05, 0.15, 0.075]) 

1912 self.buttonreset = Button(bax, 'Reset') 

1913 self.buttonreset.on_clicked(self._on_reset)

1922 def _on_reset(self, event): 

1923 with ExitStack() as stack:

1926 # invalid, depending on the order in which they are restored).

2529class SpanSelector(_SelectorWidget): 

2530 """ 

2531 Visually select a min/max range on a single axis and call a function with 

2532 those values. 

2533 

2534 To guarantee that the selector remains responsive, keep a reference to it. 

2535 

2536 In order to turn off the SpanSelector, set ``span_selector.active`` to 

2537 False. To turn it back on, set it to True. 

2538 

2539 Press and release events triggered at the same coordinates outside the 

2540 selection will clear the selector, except when 

2541 ``ignore_event_outside=True``. 

2542 

2543 Parameters 

2544 ---------- 

2545 ax : `matplotlib.axes.Axes` 

2546 

2547 onselect : callable 

2548 A callback function that is called after a release event and the 

2549 selection is created, changed or removed. 

2550 It must have the signature:: 

2551 

2552 def on_select(min: float, max: float) -> Any 

2553 

2554 direction : {"horizontal", "vertical"} 

2555 The direction along which to draw the span selector. 

2556 

2557 minspan : float, default: 0 

2558 If selection is less than or equal to *minspan*, the selection is 

2559 removed (when already existing) or cancelled. 

2560 

2561 useblit : bool, default: False 

2562 If True, use the backend-dependent blitting features for faster 

2563 canvas updates. See the tutorial :doc:`/tutorials/advanced/blitting` 

2564 for details. 

2565 

2566 props : dict, optional 

2567 Dictionary of `matplotlib.patches.Patch` properties. 

2568 Default: 

2569 

2570 ``dict(facecolor='red', alpha=0.5)`` 

2571 

2572 onmove_callback : func(min, max), min/max are floats, default: None 

2573 Called on mouse move while the span is being selected. 

2574 

2575 span_stays : bool, default: False 

2576 If True, the span stays visible after the mouse is released. 

2577 Deprecated, use *interactive* instead. 

2578 

2579 interactive : bool, default: False 

2580 Whether to draw a set of handles that allow interaction with the 

2581 widget after it is drawn. 

2582 

2583 button : `.MouseButton` or list of `.MouseButton`, default: all buttons 

2584 The mouse buttons which activate the span selector. 

2585 

2586 handle_props : dict, default: None 

2587 Properties of the handle lines at the edges of the span. Only used 

2588 when *interactive* is True. See `matplotlib.lines.Line2D` for valid 

2589 properties. 

2590 

2591 grab_range : float, default: 10 

2592 Distance in pixels within which the interactive tool handles can be 

2593 activated. 

2594 

2595 state_modifier_keys : dict, optional 

2596 Keyboard modifiers which affect the widget's behavior. Values 

2597 amend the defaults, which are: 

2598 

2599 - "clear": Clear the current shape, default: "escape". 

2600 

2601 drag_from_anywhere : bool, default: False 

2602 If `True`, the widget can be moved by clicking anywhere within 

2603 its bounds. 

2604 

2605 ignore_event_outside : bool, default: False 

2606 If `True`, the event triggered outside the span selector will be 

2607 ignored. 

2608 

2609 snap_values : 1D array-like, optional 

2610 Snap the selector edges to the given values. 

2611 

2612 Examples 

2613 -------- 

2614 >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 

2615 >>> import matplotlib.widgets as mwidgets 

2616 >>> fig, ax = plt.subplots() 

2617 >>> ax.plot([1, 2, 3], [10, 50, 100]) 

2618 >>> def onselect(vmin, vmax): 

2619 ... print(vmin, vmax) 

2620 >>> span = mwidgets.SpanSelector(ax, onselect, 'horizontal', 

2621 ... props=dict(facecolor='blue', alpha=0.5)) 

2622 >>> fig.show() 

2623 

2624 See also: :doc:`/gallery/widgets/span_selector` 

2625 """ 

2626

2931 @staticmethod 

2932 def _snap(values, snap_values): 

2933 """Snap values to a given array values (snap_values).""" 

2934 # take into account machine precision 

2935 eps = np.min(np.abs(np.diff(snap_values))) * 1e-12 

2936 return tuple( 

2937 snap_values[np.abs(snap_values - v + np.sign(v) * eps).argmin()] 

2938 for v in values)

2946 else: 

2947 vmin = self._selection_artist.get_y() 

2948 vmax = vmin + self._selection_artist.get_height() 

2949 return vmin, vmax

3414 def _onmove(self, event): 

3415 """ 

3416 Motion notify event handler. 

3417 

3418 This can do one of four things: 

3419 - Translate 

3420 - Rotate 

3421 - Re-size 

3422 - Continue the creation of a new shape 

3423 """ 

3424 eventpress = self._eventpress 

3425 # The calculations are done for rotation at zero: we apply inverse 

3426 # transformation to events except when we rotate and move 

3427 state = self._state 

3428 rotate = ('rotate' in state and 

3429 self._active_handle in self._corner_order) 

3430 move = self._active_handle == 'C' 

3431 resize = self._active_handle and not move 

3432 

3433 if resize: 

3434 inv_tr = self._get_rotation_transform().inverted() 

3435 event.xdata, event.ydata = inv_tr.transform( 

3436 [event.xdata, event.ydata]) 

3437 eventpress.xdata, eventpress.ydata = inv_tr.transform( 

3438 [eventpress.xdata, eventpress.ydata] 

3439 ) 

3440 

3441 dx = event.xdata - eventpress.xdata 

3442 dy = event.ydata - eventpress.ydata 

3443 # refmax is used when moving the corner handle with the square state 

3444 # and is the maximum between refx and refy 

3445 refmax = None 

3446 if self._use_data_coordinates: 

3447 refx, refy = dx, dy 

3448 else: 

3449 # Get dx/dy in display coordinates 

3450 refx = event.x - eventpress.x 

3451 refy = event.y - eventpress.y 

3452 

3453 x0, x1, y0, y1 = self._extents_on_press 

3454 # rotate an existing shape 

3455 if rotate: 

3456 # calculate angle abc 

3457 a = np.array([eventpress.xdata, eventpress.ydata]) 

3458 b = np.array(self.center) 

3459 c = np.array([event.xdata, event.ydata]) 

3460 angle = (np.arctan2(c[1]-b[1], c[0]-b[0]) - 

3461 np.arctan2(a[1]-b[1], a[0]-b[0])) 

3462 self.rotation = np.rad2deg(self._rotation_on_press + angle) 

3463 

3464 elif resize: 

3465 size_on_press = [x1 - x0, y1 - y0] 

3466 center = [x0 + size_on_press[0] / 2, y0 + size_on_press[1] / 2] 

3467 

3468 # Keeping the center fixed 

3469 if 'center' in state: 

3470 # hh, hw are half-height and half-width 

3471 if 'square' in state: 

3472 # when using a corner, find which reference to use 

3473 if self._active_handle in self._corner_order: 

3474 refmax = max(refx, refy, key=abs) 

3475 if self._active_handle in ['E', 'W'] or refmax == refx: 

3476 hw = event.xdata - center[0] 

3477 hh = hw / self._aspect_ratio_correction 

3478 else: 

3479 hh = event.ydata - center[1] 

3480 hw = hh * self._aspect_ratio_correction 

3481 else: 

3482 hw = size_on_press[0] / 2 

3483 hh = size_on_press[1] / 2 

3484 # cancel changes in perpendicular direction 

3485 if self._active_handle in ['E', 'W'] + self._corner_order: 3485 ↛ 3487line 3485 didn't jump to line 3487, because the condition on line 3485 was never false

3486 hw = abs(event.xdata - center[0]) 

3487 if self._active_handle in ['N', 'S'] + self._corner_order: 

3488 hh = abs(event.ydata - center[1]) 

3489 

3490 x0, x1, y0, y1 = (center[0] - hw, center[0] + hw, 

3491 center[1] - hh, center[1] + hh) 

3492 

3493 else: 

3494 # change sign of relative changes to simplify calculation 

3495 # Switch variables so that x1 and/or y1 are updated on move 

3496 if 'W' in self._active_handle: 

3497 x0 = x1 

3498 if 'S' in self._active_handle: 

3499 y0 = y1 

3500 if self._active_handle in ['E', 'W'] + self._corner_order: 3500 ↛ 3502line 3500 didn't jump to line 3502, because the condition on line 3500 was never false

3504 if 'square' in state:

3508 if self._active_handle in ['E', 'W'] or refmax == refx: 

3509 sign = np.sign(event.ydata - y0) 

3510 y1 = y0 + sign * abs(x1 - x0) / \ 

3511 self._aspect_ratio_correction 

3512 else: 

3513 sign = np.sign(event.xdata - x0) 

3514 x1 = x0 + sign * abs(y1 - y0) * \ 

3515 self._aspect_ratio_correction 

3516 

3517 elif move: 

3518 x0, x1, y0, y1 = self._extents_on_press 

3519 dx = event.xdata - eventpress.xdata 

3520 dy = event.ydata - eventpress.ydata 

3521 x0 += dx 

3522 x1 += dx 

3523 y0 += dy 

3524 y1 += dy 

3525 

3526 else: 

3527 # Create a new shape 

3528 self._rotation = 0 

3529 # Don't create a new rectangle if there is already one when 

3530 # ignore_event_outside=True 

3531 if ((self.ignore_event_outside and self._selection_completed) or 

3532 not self._allow_creation): 

3533 return 

3534 center = [eventpress.xdata, eventpress.ydata] 

3535 dx = (event.xdata - center[0]) / 2. 

3536 dy = (event.ydata - center[1]) / 2. 

3537 

3538 # square shape 

3539 if 'square' in state: 

3540 refmax = max(refx, refy, key=abs) 

3541 if refmax == refx: 

3542 dy = np.sign(dy) * abs(dx) / self._aspect_ratio_correction 

3543 else: 

3544 dx = np.sign(dx) * abs(dy) * self._aspect_ratio_correction 

3545 

3546 # from center 

3547 if 'center' in state:

3549 dy *= 2

3551 # from corner

3553 center[0] += dx 

3554 center[1] += dy 

3555 

3556 x0, x1, y0, y1 = (center[0] - dx, center[0] + dx, 

3557 center[1] - dy, center[1] + dy) 

3558

3573 def _get_rotation_transform(self): 

3574 aspect_ratio = self.ax._get_aspect_ratio() 

3575 return Affine2D().translate(-self.center[0], -self.center[1]) \ 

3576 .scale(1, aspect_ratio) \

3683 # Set active handle as closest handle, if mouse click is close enough. 

3684 elif m_dist < self.grab_range * 2:

3840class PolygonSelector(_SelectorWidget): 

3841 """ 

3842 Select a polygon region of an Axes. 

3843 

3844 Place vertices with each mouse click, and make the selection by completing 

3845 the polygon (clicking on the first vertex). Once drawn individual vertices 

3846 can be moved by clicking and dragging with the left mouse button, or 

3847 removed by clicking the right mouse button. 

3848 

3849 In addition, the following modifier keys can be used: 

3850 

3851 - Hold *ctrl* and click and drag a vertex to reposition it before the 

3852 polygon has been completed. 

3853 - Hold the *shift* key and click and drag anywhere in the Axes to move 

3854 all vertices. 

3855 - Press the *esc* key to start a new polygon. 

3856 

3857 For the selector to remain responsive you must keep a reference to it. 

3858 

3859 Parameters 

3860 ---------- 

3861 ax : `~matplotlib.axes.Axes` 

3862 The parent Axes for the widget. 

3863 

3864 onselect : function 

3865 When a polygon is completed or modified after completion, 

3866 the *onselect* function is called and passed a list of the vertices as 

3867 ``(xdata, ydata)`` tuples. 

3868 

3869 useblit : bool, default: False 

3870 Whether to use blitting for faster drawing (if supported by the 

3871 backend). See the tutorial :doc:`/tutorials/advanced/blitting` 

3872 for details. 

3873 

3874 props : dict, optional 

3875 Properties with which the line is drawn, see `matplotlib.lines.Line2D` 

3876 for valid properties. 

3877 Default: 

3878 

3879 ``dict(color='k', linestyle='-', linewidth=2, alpha=0.5)`` 

3880 

3881 handle_props : dict, optional 

3882 Artist properties for the markers drawn at the vertices of the polygon. 

3883 See the marker arguments in `matplotlib.lines.Line2D` for valid 

3884 properties. Default values are defined in ``mpl.rcParams`` except for 

3885 the default value of ``markeredgecolor`` which will be the same as the 

3886 ``color`` property in *props*. 

3887 

3888 grab_range : float, default: 10 

3889 A vertex is selected (to complete the polygon or to move a vertex) if 

3890 the mouse click is within *grab_range* pixels of the vertex. 

3891 

3892 draw_bounding_box : bool, optional 

3893 If `True`, a bounding box will be drawn around the polygon selector 

3894 once it is complete. This box can be used to move and resize the 

3895 selector. 

3896 

3897 box_handle_props : dict, optional 

3898 Properties to set for the box handles. See the documentation for the 

3899 *handle_props* argument to `RectangleSelector` for more info. 

3900 

3901 box_props : dict, optional 

3902 Properties to set for the box. See the documentation for the *props* 

3903 argument to `RectangleSelector` for more info. 

3904 

3905 Examples 

3906 -------- 

3907 :doc:`/gallery/widgets/polygon_selector_simple` 

3908 :doc:`/gallery/widgets/polygon_selector_demo` 

3909 

3910 Notes 

3911 ----- 

3912 If only one point remains after removing points, the selector reverts to an 

3913 incomplete state and you can start drawing a new polygon from the existing 

3914 point. 

3915 """ 

3916

4096 def _onmove(self, event): 

4097 """Cursor move event handler.""" 

4098 # Move the active vertex (ToolHandle). 

4099 if self._active_handle_idx >= 0: 

4100 idx = self._active_handle_idx 

4101 self._xys[idx] = event.xdata, event.ydata 

4102 # Also update the end of the polygon line if the first vertex is 

4103 # the active handle and the polygon is completed. 

4104 if idx == 0 and self._selection_completed: 

4105 self._xys[-1] = event.xdata, event.ydata 

4106 

4107 # Move all vertices. 

4108 elif 'move_all' in self._state and self._eventpress: 

4109 dx = event.xdata - self._eventpress.xdata 

4110 dy = event.ydata - self._eventpress.ydata 

4111 for k in range(len(self._xys)): 

4112 x_at_press, y_at_press = self._xys_at_press[k] 

4113 self._xys[k] = x_at_press + dx, y_at_press + dy 

4114 

4115 # Do nothing if completed or waiting for a move. 

4116 elif (self._selection_completed 

4117 or 'move_vertex' in self._state or 'move_all' in self._state): 

4118 return 

4119 

4120 # Position pending vertex. 

4121 else: 

4122 # Calculate distance to the start vertex. 

4123 x0, y0 = \ 

4124 self._selection_artist.get_transform().transform(self._xys[0]) 

4125 v0_dist = np.hypot(x0 - event.x, y0 - event.y) 

4126 # Lock on to the start vertex if near it and ready to complete.

4128 self._xys[-1] = self._xys[0]

4138 if (not self._selection_completed 

4139 and ('move_vertex' in self._state or 

4140 'move_all' in self._state)): 

4141 self._xys.pop() 

4142 self._draw_polygon() 

4143 

4144 def _on_key_release(self, event): 

4145 """Key release event handler.""" 

4146 # Add back the pending vertex if leaving the 'move_vertex' or 

4147 # 'move_all' mode (by checking the released key) 

4148 if (not self._selection_completed 

4149 and 

4150 (event.key == self._state_modifier_keys.get('move_vertex') 

4151 or event.key == self._state_modifier_keys.get('move_all'))): 

4152 self._xys.append((event.xdata, event.ydata)) 

4153 self._draw_polygon() 

4154 # Reset the polygon if the released key is the 'clear' key. 

4155 elif event.key == self._state_modifier_keys.get('clear'): 

4156 event = self._clean_event(event) 

4157 self._xys = [(event.xdata, event.ydata)] 

4158 self._selection_completed = False 

4159 self._remove_box() 

4160 self.set_visible(True) 

4161 

4162 def _draw_polygon(self): 

4163 """Redraw the polygon based on the new vertex positions.""" 

4164 xs, ys = zip(*self._xys) if self._xys else ([], []) 

4165 self._selection_artist.set_data(xs, ys) 

4166 self._update_box() 

4167 # Only show one tool handle at the start and end vertex of the polygon 

4168 # if the polygon is completed or the user is locked on to the start 

4169 # vertex. 

4170 if (self._selection_completed 

4171 or (len(self._xys) > 3 

4172 and self._xys[-1] == self._xys[0])): 

4173 self._polygon_handles.set_data(xs[:-1], ys[:-1]) 

4174 else: 

4175 self._polygon_handles.set_data(xs, ys) 

4176 self.update() 

4177 

4178 @property 

4179 def verts(self): 

4180 """The polygon vertices, as a list of ``(x, y)`` pairs.""" 

4181 return self._xys[:-1] 

4182 

4183 @verts.setter 

4184 def verts(self, xys): 

4185 """ 

4186 Set the polygon vertices. 

4187 

4188 This will remove any preexisting vertices, creating a complete polygon 

4189 with the new vertices. 

4190 """ 

4191 self._xys = [*xys, xys[0]] 

4192 self._selection_completed = True 

4193 self.set_visible(True) 

4194 if self._draw_box and self._box is None: 

4195 self._add_box() 

4196 self._draw_polygon() 

4197 

4198 

4199class Lasso(AxesWidget): 

4200 """ 

4201 Selection curve of an arbitrary shape. 

4202 

4203 The selected path can be used in conjunction with 

4204 `~matplotlib.path.Path.contains_point` to select data points from an image. 

4205 

4206 Unlike `LassoSelector`, this must be initialized with a starting 

4207 point *xy*, and the `Lasso` events are destroyed upon release. 

4208 

4209 Parameters 

4210 ---------- 

4211 ax : `~matplotlib.axes.Axes` 

4212 The parent Axes for the widget. 

4213 xy : (float, float) 

4214 Coordinates of the start of the lasso. 

4215 callback : callable 

4216 Whenever the lasso is released, the *callback* function is called and 

4217 passed the vertices of the selected path. 

4218 useblit : bool, default: True 

4219 Whether to use blitting for faster drawing (if supported by the 

4220 backend). See the tutorial :doc:`/tutorials/advanced/blitting` 

4221 for details. 

4222 """ 

4223 

4224 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.7", name="useblit") 

4225 def __init__(self, ax, xy, callback, useblit=True): 

4226 super().__init__(ax) 

4227 

4228 self.useblit = useblit and self.canvas.supports_blit 

4229 if self.useblit: 

4230 self.background = self.canvas.copy_from_bbox(self.ax.bbox) 

4231 

4232 x, y = xy 

4233 self.verts = [(x, y)] 

4234 self.line = Line2D([x], [y], linestyle='-', color='black', lw=2) 

4235 self.ax.add_line(self.line) 

4236 self.callback = callback 

4237 self.connect_event('button_release_event', self.onrelease) 

4238 self.connect_event('motion_notify_event', self.onmove) 

4239 

4240 def onrelease(self, event): 

4241 if self.ignore(event): 

4242 return 

4243 if self.verts is not None: 

4244 self.verts.append((event.xdata, event.ydata)) 

4245 if len(self.verts) > 2: 

4246 self.callback(self.verts) 

4247 self.ax.lines.remove(self.line) 

4248 self.verts = None 

4249 self.disconnect_events() 

4250 

4251 def onmove(self, event): 

4252 if self.ignore(event): 

4253 return 

4254 if self.verts is None: 

4255 return 

4256 if event.inaxes != self.ax: 

4257 return 

4258 if event.button != 1: 

4259 return 

4260 self.verts.append((event.xdata, event.ydata)) 

4261 

4262 self.line.set_data(list(zip(*self.verts))) 

4263 

4264 if self.useblit: 

4265 self.canvas.restore_region(self.background) 

4266 self.ax.draw_artist(self.line) 

4267 self.canvas.blit(self.ax.bbox) 

4268 else: 

4269 self.canvas.draw_idle()
